repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian
            Peoples Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian Peoples Development Project for Ecuador was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that a project design which
            emphasizes decentralized implementation is crucial for
            successfully dealing with ethnic and cultural diversity of
            beneficiaries. The mobilization of labor and capital can be
            an effective vehicle for promoting local employment and
            growth. Piloting procedures should speed up the project
            implementation and improve results. Ensuring that training
            be given to beneficiary groups will result in a successful
            implementation of small investment subprojects. Transfer of
            land in environmentally fragile protected areas may require
            an accommodating legal framework which confirms the unique
            access to those land by indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian
            communities, based upon ancestral rights.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian
            Peoples Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian Peoples Development Project is to improve
            the quality of life of poor rural indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian communities by providing improved access to
            land resources and financing for investment subprojects
            planned and implemented by local membership organizations
            and communities. The project components are four. The first
            strengthens second and third tier indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian membership organizations in 1) subproject
            participatory planning, preparation, implementation, and
            maintenance; 2) financial management and administration; 3)
            cultural patrimony; and 4) human resources development,
            including basic legal training. This component focuses on
            seven small ethnic groups in danger of extinction, and also
            finances goods and equipment and incremental operating
            costs. The second component 1) titles and regularizes land
            tenure rights in productive, forestry, and protected areas;
            2) purchases land; 3) diagnoses and elaborates an action
            plan for community-owned irrigation systems; and 4) supports
            a program of legal reforms. It also strengthens public
            sector agencies. The third component finances demand-driven
            small-scale investments in natural resources management;
            community-based economic infrastructure; social
            infrastructure; and economic projects and micro-enterprises.
            The fourth component provides institutional strengthening of
            the National Council of Indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian Development.
